audit_report:
1. YES
2. - Arbitrary code execution via unsafe dynamic import: line 17 (c = import_module(t).Auth). If cfg["auth"]["type"] is attacker-controlled, arbitrary modules can be imported and executed.
   - Authentication bypass (insecure “None” mode): lines 12–14 and 28–30 (NoneAuth returns True). Selecting type "None" disables authentication entirely.
   - Weak/insecure password storage/verification:
     - Plaintext: lines 42–43 and 66–67 (hv == pw). Stores/verifies passwords in clear; trivially compromised.
     - SHA-1: lines 40–41 and 72–77. SHA-1 is cryptographically broken and very fast to brute-force.
     - SSHA (salted SHA-1): lines 38–39 and 79–87. Still based on SHA-1; fast and weak against modern cracking.
     - apr1 MD5: lines 44–49 and 92–93. MD5-based scheme is outdated and fast to brute-force compared to modern KDFs.
     - crypt(): lines 57–62 and 69–70. System crypt may default to weak/low-cost schemes; strength not enforced.
   - Timing side-channel on authentication outcome: lines 101–103. Success returns immediately while failure sleeps 1–2s, enabling attackers to detect valid credential pairs by response time.
   - Non-constant-time hash comparisons: lines 66–67, 69–70, 77, 87. Using == can leak slight timing differences; use hmac.compare_digest to mitigate.
   - Information leakage in error messages: lines 48, 54, 61, 64. Detailed RuntimeError messages expose configuration/back-end details that may aid attackers.
3. N/A
4. N/A

CVE Description: Radicale before 1.1.2 and 2.x before 2.0.0rc2 is prone to timing oracles and simple brute-force attacks when using the htpasswd authentication method.
CWE: ['CWE-362']

audit_report:
1. YES.
2. Insecure TLS (ssl=False) — in _async_get_child_links_recursive when creating aiohttp.ClientSession: connector=aiohttp.TCPConnector(ssl=False) — disables HTTPS verification, enabling MITM; SSRF/redirect bypass — requests.get(url, ...) and session.get(url) (both follow redirects by default, no allowlist; prevent_outside only filters extracted links) — attacker-controlled URL/redirect can reach internal services (e.g., 169.254.169.254); ReDoS via user-supplied regex — link_regex passed to extract_sub_links — catastrophic backtracking on crafted patterns; DoS via unbounded crawl/concurrency and no response size limits — building sub_tasks for each to_visit without cap and loading response.text fully — resource exhaustion; Potential secret header leakage — headers forwarded in requests/aiohttp and followed across redirects — tokens/headers may be exposed to other hosts.
3. N/A.
4. N/A.

- No unsafe operations (e.g., command execution, unsafe deserialization, direct filesystem writes to sensitive paths) are present. File access is mocked (storage_manager.open/exists), and HTTP fetching is mocked where used.
- Any real security concerns (SSRF, path traversal, header handling, zip creation) would be in the production code under test (geonode.proxy.views, download views, helpers), which is not part of this snippet.

CVE Description: GeoNode is an open source platform that facilitates the creation, sharing, and collaborative use of geospatial data. In versions 3.2.0 through 4.1.2, the endpoint `/proxy/?url=` does not properly protect against server-side request forgery. This allows an attacker to port scan internal hosts and request information from internal hosts. A patch is available at commit a9eebae80cb362009660a1fd49e105e7cdb499b9.
CWE: ['CWE-918']

audit_report:
1. YES.
2. Vulnerabilities: DoS via unbounded input buffering and message size (data_received: lines ~45, 59–63) — header.body_size isn’t capped and self._d accumulates, allowing memory exhaustion; DoS via unbounded asyncio.Queue (lines ~20, 62) — queue has no maxsize, attacker can flood messages; No transport encryption (start: line ~102) — create_server runs without SSL/TLS, enabling sniffing/MitM unless higher-layer OPC UA security is enforced; Log injection/info exposure (lines ~23, 27, 52, 56, 80, 107) — logs include unsanitized, attacker-controlled values and session info, enabling CRLF/escape-sequence log forging and leakage; Slowloris/connection churn DoS (lines ~51–54 and generally 44–61) — partial headers trigger immediate close and there are no timeouts/backpressure (no pause_writing/resume_writing), enabling resource exhaustion.

CVE Description: Versions of the package asyncua before 0.9.96 are vulnerable to Denial of Service (DoS) such that an attacker can send a malformed packet and as a result, the server will enter into an infinite loop and consume excessive memory.
CWE: ['CWE-835']
CWE Description:

audit_report:
1. YES
2. - CSV/Spreadsheet Formula Injection (improper neutralization) — vulnerable at the line "if type(v) is str:" inside export_resource: only exact built-in str values are sanitized; str subclasses (e.g., Django’s SafeString) and non-str objects with attacker-controlled __str__() bypass the check and can start with =, +, -, or @, executing as formulas in spreadsheet apps.
   - Inadequate mitigation strategy (destructive stripping instead of safe prefixing) — vulnerable in the while loop that removes leading special characters: stripping characters alters data and is not a robust neutralization; best practice is to consistently prefix risky values (e.g., with a single quote) after coercing all values to str, ensuring no formula is executed.
3. N/A
4. N/A
